Text: Back in 1970 I had a paper route, two actually. I had just finished delivering my papers one day, and went into my hang-out pizza place to play a few games of pinball before heading home for dinner. I walked in and saw a couple of kids in front of a black and white TV screen. I walked over and saw that they were playing a computer game. It was called Pong. I still clearly remember the thought in my head at that time. "The world has changed. My world has changed." I built my first gaming computer, before the term gaming computers began to be used, back when Windows 95 was a new operating system. From where I am sitting, as I play around with Gemini 2.5, the world is about to change, in ways we cannot even conceive. Buckle up!

Text: The thing that always concerns me with videos like this, is that they just look at the positives of these different periods of innovations. Take the post civil war error that he mentioned. Yes there was great economic growth for a number of people, particularly those who ventured west, claimed land, and benefited from a booming economy. But this was also the period where the railroad opened up every natural resoruce of the west, facilitated the slaughter of Native americans and many wildlife species & ecosystems (think bison, passenger pigeons, wolves & grizzlies), and kick started our addiction to fossil fuels, which arguably has killed 100x times more people around the world since the civil war than the actual war did itself. The same can be applied to the industrial boom of the 40-70''s. Yes there was great economic opportunity for people after the war, but it really laid the ground for the addictions we face today centred around personal automobiles, cheap consumer items, and heavily processed food, and the challenges we also face around housing and cost of living. And then the start of the digital age helped to connect the world in so many ways, and created the globalised society we today live in, but the negatives around being addicted to online spaces, and the impact that has on our relationships, careers, and personal wellbeing is never addressed by the same players that created said circumstances. For every step forward humanity makes, we often take 10 steps back if innovation occurs rapidly without giving us time to think, plan and regulate effectively.   And by my estimation, this next technological boom will result in exactly the same thing. AI might make our daily lives more efficient, but because those efficiency improvements are most commonly focused around human labour needs, it will just result in mass joblessness. And the thought that this would actually be redistributed is fanciful, as the technology is wielded by just the top 0.001% of society, that also have incredible influence over the governments of the world. In short, there is no way that these gains will actually be shared across the world. Yes renewables may help us overcome our addiction to fossil fuels, bit it creates a new addiction to various rare earth elements that nations are currently fighting wars over, the control of which will also dictate the flow of money to the citizens of the world. And the promises around CRISPR technology is definitely impressive, but it could also be terrifying if used to create super viruses, unkillable bacteria, or diseases the target specific ethnicities or genetic groups. Or even if it isn''t intentionally used for mass harm, what if the lab cultured beef unknowingly creates the perfect environment for ultra transmissible strains of mad cow, TB, Brucelosis, and since the tissue is not contained within a body with a functioning immune system, those pathogens spread quickly to the consumers buying said product? When technologies rapidly develop, and we just kick back and let it run it''s course, they arguably do more harm than good over the long run, by concentrating power with those who are irresponsible to wield it, and creating a litany of unintended consequences that we can''t turn back the clock on.

Text: I''m a bit skeptical on these divisions and what makes people choose those and not others. Wasn''t 1970s to 2000s an equally crazy boom of progress that went from sending us to the moon with basically mechanical calculators to the digital age of the internet, prompting people to abandon living outdoors for living predominantly indoors and virtually. To me it''s not entirely convincing to break up history in similar chunk with similar pauses in between. The rate of change and development has been increasing logarithmically so I can''t really compare 250 years ago to today''s development cycles.  (Also on the point of clean energy, it''s a bit reductive to say that solar energy for example is a technology and not a commodity. It still requires extraction of resources, but rather than large quantities of bulk resources instead now relies on extremely rare, difficult to extract resources. It''s still a positive regardless, but mostly since it doesn''t rely on irreplaceable organic material, but instead on elements we can find easily all over the solar system. Just good to keep in mind currently it still requires extraction on earth, and exploitation of our fellow humans)
